messageBody:
To me "a class" = "a unit". Most of my "factory" unit tests feed the
factory various types of inputs and verify the created object(s) are
correct. I don't bother testing individual methods, but rather I test
behavior. If I can't test a certain type of behavior, I break out code into
other classes until I can test that behavior.

For example, I would never test the sortByDptrDate method directly. I would
build an itinerary and verify that the returned object is sorted by
departure date.

The createUniqueItins and createAllItins methods seem like "strategies" to
me. Could you turn those methods into separate classes with their own
tests? The ItinBuilder would use the strategies, but the strategy code
would be tested elsewhere.

I'm a bit confused about how this class is actually used. There is one
public method with no return values. How does a client get an itinerary
after it's built? Maybe an example of some client code would help the
discussion.

Matt

Subject: [junit] Design question: was Testing Private Methods


Folks,
Would greatly appreciate some help here:
If this is not the right forum, do let me know.

I'd like to take a piece of code and get suggestions on how to do it
differently:
Consider a class called ItinBuilder.
Given a bunch of flight legs, it builds itineraries. Simple enough.
Except:
1. it can have alternate legs e.g going from A to B at different times.
2. have to differentiate departing itins from return itins
e.g. A-B-C -> departing
C-A -> return
C-B-A -> return
etc. etc.
To cut a long story short, assume i have put the following methods
public class ItinBuilder
{
public void buildItins(segment[] segs);

private sortByDptrDate();
private identifyDupeSegs();
private createUniqueItins(); // ignores duplicates
private createAllItins(); // builds all itins based on the
unique itins using dupes
}

So really, a "client" only needs to call buildItins(), but the real work
happens in the
private methods which therefore need to be tested.
Assumption:
we'd like to keep our tests in a separate package.

Any suggestions are greatly appreciated. Sorry about the length of this
e-mail.
Nilesh
